definition: A magnetic resonance imaging scan that uses strong magnetic fields to produce detailed images of organs and tissues.
A computed tomography scan combines a series of X-ray images taken from different angles to create cross-sectional views.
A diagnostic tool that uses radiation to view internal structures of the body, especially bones.
A technique that uses high-frequency sound waves to produce images of structures within your body.
A positron emission tomography scan is an imaging test that helps reveal how tissues and organs are functioning.
A test that measures the electrical activity of the heartbeat.
A test used to evaluate the electrical activity in the brain.
A procedure to remove a piece of tissue or a sample of cells from your body so that it can be analyzed.
A nonsurgical procedure used to examine a person's digestive tract using an endoscope.
A lab analysis performed on a blood sample used to check for diseases, conditions, and overall health.
